instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165A: What is 820-00165A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Im working on a Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which was water damaged and was dead with no led on charger.
I currently have it powering up fan spin. All major voltage are present.
I have no chime or screen and am not sure of usb activity but usb mouse red led flickers at the start of power up.

Currently I have no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and no output from Q77706. <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> has power on pins C4/D1/C1 but no output .
The unit draws about 350ma.
L7701 ha no voltage on it due to <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> not passing voltage pins 3 and 4 have 8v.

i have flashed the bios with a file from the forum but still the same.
Any help welcomed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
USB mouse light should be steady, but can trick you.
Always better to use USB boot pendrive with Link LED; if flashes, then 100% USB activity confirmed.
No reason to search video, if no USB activity on board...

If water damage, first step should be reball SMC and check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Maybe need to heat CPU with good flux and UC the board too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Will try that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Smc reball worked. Boots fine but has uneven backlight (shadow acrodd 1/3rd of the screen)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check all return resistors in backlight circuit.
Try known good compatible LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes I tried 2 screens 1 cracked and the backlight is the same on both, will try the return resistors.
Thank you for the assistance.

Edit.. <SIGNAL>LED_RETURN_2</SIGNAL> using diode mode is reading .019 all the rest are .63 so I guess <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> is bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I seem to have sorted out the backlight issue but when testing the battery to see if it charges I now have another issues. The system doesnt see the battery or charge it.
With just the battery in I get 8.23v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> F7140.  
I have 8.23v on pins 1-3 on batt connector , pins 4 and 5 3.3v fluctuates frpm 3.3 - 3.0 on both pins. Pin 6 is at 0.22v.
<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR>/52 read ok 
I have tried 3 different batteries

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What voltage on PPBUS with just the charger no battery? If 8.23, you have a bad SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sounds like bad batteries to me...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No I have 1 charging and running off the same model board in a different chasis.
So this battery has some charge and will power up on the other chasis but wont on the one Im working on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Post diode mode readings and voltage on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: .53 on both from batt connector

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If both readings equal, and voltages too (only you know if), try other SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have 8.23v on pins 1-3 on batt connector
3.3v on both SCL/SDA lines.

Os does not see a battery. Everything else works fine. I managed to install fresh Os. So there doesn't seem to be any other issues other than seeing the presence of the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I was asking about SCL/SDA voltage, apart of diode mode reading.
If both steady 3.3V, change SMC.
You can try changing <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> first, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi as previously mentioned SCL/SDA voltages are 3.3v . Isl was changed for new one but still the same.

How to know if the board sees the battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Fluctuation there could be sign of SMC activity.
An o-scope can clarify that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes definite activity on SCL/SDA using scope

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Reballed the Smc an seems to be working now, charges and runs from battery . Will test more. There must be an easier way to align these smc chips?.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, scratch the board around the chip, before removing.
Be aware, do not break the traces!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
HI thanks, must be a bad smc as it only works sometimes when heated so will replace the smc.

Replaced Smc and all good now.
